Award.AwardTitle: Elucidating molecular mechanisms of the iron deficiency response in plants

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Elucidating molecular mechanisms of the iron deficiency response in plants
Intellectual Merit: The ability to respond to fluctuations in nutritional availability is critical for all living cells. Multicellular organisms can respond to such challenges by altering a number of physiological, developmental and molecular processes that are often controlled at the level of transcription. While conventional molecular biology and physiological approaches have revealed the importance of genes involved in nutrient uptake and transport, few transcriptional regulators have been identified that coordinate organismal responses to nutrient availability. This research focuses on the following questions: What transcription factors regulate the response to iron deprivation in plants? How do these transcription factors interact with each other and other proteins to regulate gene expression? Is there a protein complex that acts as an iron sensing mechanism in plant roots that reacts and leads to the classic response to low iron? Since plant iron transporters translocate other metals nonspecifically, studying this mechanism will further inform us about homeostasis of other metals. Moreover, the protein-protein interactions that we will examine shares features with an iron sensing and response mechanism recently described in mammalian cells and would, therefore, shed new light on conserved iron sensing and response mechanisms.

Broader Impacts: Iron deficiency, which causes anemia, is the most prevalent nutritional disorder in the world. Approximately 30% of the world's population is iron deficient, which results in increased maternal mortality and infant loss, impaired growth and cognitive development and decreased immune response. In addition, iron deficiency is a global problem for the growth of major crops grown in calcareous soils. This project proposes to increase our understanding of how plants respond to iron deprivation with the long term goal of producing plants with enhanced nutritional capacity and tolerance of nutrient-poor soils, thus increasing our ability to address increasing global nutritional needs. In addition to agricultural and nutritional contributions, this project will create resources for the scientific community at large, including a new model for how iron content is sensed within cells. Moreover, the project will provide unique research opportunities for students, in particular, underrepresented minority groups attending smaller historically black colleges and universities. Thus, the project will help to increase the dept and breath of molecular and plant biology researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Iron is an essential component of many critical proteins and metabolic processes for almost all species on earth. Iron deficiency is the most prevalent nutritional disorder in the world, affecting human health from immune resistance to overall productivity. Most people obtain iron primarily from plants, therefore, understanding how plants respond to iron deficiency stress with the specific purpose of biofortification, could significantly impact human health. Previously, we identified POPEYE (PYE), an important transcription factor that mediates response to low iron in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana, along with BRUTUS (BTS), which, when disrupted, leads to increased tolerance to iron deficiency. BTS encodes a unique plant protein with three putative iron binding hemerythrin (HHE) motifs, as well as a RING motif that could facilitate degradation of interacting proteins. Loss of BTS function leads to embryo lethality. Moreover, BTS physically interacts with putative PYE-like (PYEL) transcription factors such as ILR3, which also interact with one another. Based upon these data we proposed that BTS is an allosteric protein that binds iron and facilitates the degradation of PYEL proteins, and that the interaction between BTS, PYE, and PYELs could play a critical role in sensing the iron status within the root and subsequently triggering regulatory responses to iron deprivation. The major goals of the project were to test these hypotheses, enabling us to elucidate a basic iron sensing mechanism that coordinates regulatory responses involved in plant iron uptake.

We found that loss of BTS function leads to increased seed iron content, which is correlated with elevated embryo lethality and alterations in iron localization. Moreover, we found that BTS binds Fe, specifically at the three hemerythrin domains and that stability and function of BTS as in E3 ligase is increased in the absence of the HHE domains. BTS and PYE interact with several PYELs, including the transcription factors, ILR3 and bHLH115 in planta. Similar to PYE, ILR3 controls response to iron deprivation. The BTS E3 ligase domain is required for its interaction with ILR3 and bHLH115, which leads to the subsequent 26S proteasome-mediated degradation of both transcription factors. We also found that in the presence of increasing amounts of both soluble and insoluble iron that BTS is increasingly destabilized. These findings provide evidence that indeed BTS is an iron binding protein that interacts with and facilitates the degradation of transcription factors that control response to iron deprivation. This nutrient sensing mechanism is particularly novel because iron binding leads to instability of the iron-binding protein. Thus, BTS, which transcriptionally accumulates in the absence of iron, could restrain the responses mediated by PYE/PYEL, thus modulating or fine tuning the iron deficiency responses ensuring sufficient, yet not excess iron uptake. Once sufficient iron accumulates, PYE, PYEL, and BTS are no longer transcriptionally activated, and we theorize that BTS is maintained at minimal levels through iron-mediated regulation via the HHE domains. Such control would enable BTS to accumulate under low iron and consequently mediate degradation of regulatory targets, yet be rapidly decreased when iron is once again available.

We have also made strides in understanding the dynamics of PYE movement and the function of PYE and ILR3 in other stress responses. Furthermore, we have been able to identify other proteins associated with PYE and BTS, and have found several new iron response players using screening approaches. This work has not only shed new light on how plants respond to nutrient stress, which is important for generating plants with elevated nutrient content and tolerance to nutrient poor-soils, but also provided unique training opportunities for students from diverse backgrounds.
